awd_titl_txt: Probing the Active Phase of Cluster Galaxy Evolution with Active Galactic Nuclei
awd_abstract_narration:
In the past, galaxies in massive clusters often had extra sources of energy in their inner regions.  But the incidence of these so-called active galactic nuclei (AGNs) has declined over time.  This decline means that galaxies in crowded galaxy neighborhoods are evolving.  To help understand that evolution, the team will analyze observations of about 2000 distant clusters at radio, infrared and optical wavelengths.  Senior team members will train junior team members.  The team will also partner with Florida's Center for Precollegiate Education and Training.  Via that STEM partnership, the team will develop materials to train high-school students and teachers.

The team will use observations to investigate the distribution, frequency, and properties of AGNs in massive clusters of galaxies at a redshift of about one.  The team's goals are (1) to quantify the spatial distribution of AGNs as a function of environment and redshift, to isolate the physical factors that trigger AGNs, (2) to determine the impact of a cluster's halo mass on the AGN associated with its central galaxy, and (3) to constrain the duty cycle and energetic feedback from the AGNs in the brightest cluster galaxies.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this research program was to better understand the properties of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), which are supermassive black holes that are accreting mass, in galaxies that reside in the dense environments of galaxy clusters. A specific question that we set out to address was whether the galaxy cluster environment influences the likelihood that a galaxy hosts an AGN. If yes, then we aimed to use the distribution of AGN in galaxy clusters to investigate what about this environment matters. For this work we studied a sample of galaxy clusters at a distance such that we are observing them 6 billion years in the past, a time when galaxies in clusters were more active and with more star formation than present day.

We found that a galaxy in a cluster is more likely to host an AGN than a similar field galaxy, and that there is a radial dependence -- galaxies in the center are most likely to host an AGN. We also found that there is a strong time dependence in the sense that at this epoch the probability is a factor of ten higher than present day for a cluster galaxy to have an AGN that is a strong radio source, and that the most massive galaxies are more likely to host radio AGN. We also found evidence than when galaxy clusters collide and merge the galaxies are affected by this merger and the fraction hosting AGN increases. Finally, we observed that the hot intracluster gas appears to confine jets of radio emission coming from the AGN and thus the jets in the densest regions of clusters are typically smaller.

The overall picture that we obtain from this work is that environment is an important factor in driving AGN activity, particular in driving radio-loud AGN, though it is not the only factor driving the evolution of these sources. Mergers in particular appear to play an important role and the hot intracluster gas acts to regulate the properties of radio jets. The results of this work appear in a series of five refereed publications, and two graduate students completed their dissertations as part of this project.

Complementary to this research, the PI also worked with the Center for Precollegiate Education and Training at UF to develop and implement an astronomy component in the "Research Immersion in Science and Engineering" program, which is a residential program for 9th grade students. This effort involved both graduate and undergraduate students, providing them with experience teaching hands-on activities.


Last Modified: 01/03/2022
Modified by: Anthony Gonzalez
